reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed April 2009, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: I stayed at Iwaso with my husband at the tail end of a 3-week trip in Japan. In terms of value for money, it is difficult to say. While I am happy to have stayed here, it is extremely expensive. The food was excellent and the service was very good.
reviews.title: Iwaso - A peaceful stay on Miyajima

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed June 2009, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: Rooms: The rooms are very large. We had a standard size room that was actually two rooms, in addition to the balcony/patio and bathroom. Opening up the screens, we were surrounded by a beautiful landscape on all sides.
reviews.title: A little more rustic than I wanted but wonderful staff and location

reviews.text: Food: The food is excellent. We were served multi-course meals for breakfast and dinner. While the individual dishes were no better than what we had in restaurants elsewhere in Japan, considering we were served in our rooms on the island of Miyajima, we were impressed.
reviews.title: Understated elegance and luxury, a perfect ryokan

reviews.text: Location: Iwaso provides a shuttle service to/from the pier that ferries to the mainland. From there, you can catch the train to pretty much anywhere. We arrived after a long day of train travel from Kanazawa (with a stop in Himeji to see the castle). The following day we caught the train to Hiroshima (20-30 minutes). We left here in the morning to catch an afternoon flight back to the U.S. from Kansai Airport.
reviews.title: Charming Iwaso on unforgettable Miyajima

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed November 2008, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: Like one other review I read for Iwaso, I was spoiled by an earlier ryokan stay (Gion Hatanaka in Kyoto) that was truly a once in a lifetime experience. The food there was just a little better, the service a little more attentive, etc. However, in an absolute sense, the stay on Iwaso was extraordinary. One thing that Iwaso has on all the others is the view and setting. Listening to the gentle stream and looking out onto the lush mountainside and beautiful landscaping is an experience that is hard to convey with photos. My husband and I slept as well as we ever have.
reviews.title: A Very Privileged Position.

likes.disliked: — Poorer value, noisy room 515 and no English channels.

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed October 2008, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: I booked a night at the Iwaso through Japanese Guest Houses, and it was the first of three hot spring guesthouses I stayed at.
reviews.title: Memorable hotspring experience

likes.liked: — Hot spring, food, location, surrounding gardens.
likes.disliked: — Very professional but not too personable or friendly.

reviews.text: The location was very easy to reach, however don't try to walk from the boat to the guest house - ask the information center to call you the free shuttle. The room was a very good size and very clean. The food was extraordinary, and don't even bother to ask what you are eating - everything was delicious, and too difficult to explain what the ingredients would be anyway. Someone mentioned the temperature of the hot spring to be not hot enough - I actually preferred it because it let me enjoy the hot spring for longer.
reviews.title: Fabulous food and service, but rooms and corridor need updating

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed September 2008, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: I rate the Iwaso above average because it truly is - the ambiance, location, hot spring, food were extraordinary. The only reason I am holding back in rating it "excellent" is the fact that everyone was very polite and professional, however it was missing a friendly and personal touch.
reviews.title: a little deer

likes.liked: — Tradtional ryokan on a beautiful island near the Torii gate and backing onto forest
likes.disliked: — it cost us a lot for one night- $A650

reviews.text: Despite what the Japanese Guest Houses e-mail says, you can pay by credit card - fantastic considering the bill for two people was $500 Canadian.
reviews.title: great!

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed September 2008, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: Our one night at Iwaso was our big splurge during our trip to Japan. Miyajima is a beautiful island and Iwaso is right on the edge of the forest.
reviews.title: Magical destination

likes.disliked: — Price and room tired and very basic. Futon paper thin

reviews.text: This is a lovely Ryokan on Miyajima Island. It is in a beautiful forested setting. It is a good home base for seeing Hiroshima.
reviews.title: Lovely Ryokan in a Forest Setting

likes.disliked: — The breakfast was a bit touristy (at western tables in the ryokan restaurant).

reviews.text: The rooms are traditional ryokan rooms, with tatami mats. The room that we had was actually quite spacious and the futons were comfortable.
reviews.title: Elegant ryokan in a great location

reviews.text: The food was great, ours was served to us in a traditional ryokan room across the hall (other ryokans serve you in your own room). There were many seafood and a couple of beef dishes, everything was absolutely fabulous.
reviews.title: Expensive but nice experience

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed April 2008, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: The breakfast was served in the restaurant (you can get either a japanese or western breakfast), where you sat at western style tables (it seemed a bit touristy).
reviews.title: Loved the experience

likes.liked: — It was unique, clean and comfortable.

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed April 2008, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: There is internet access (I think that it was 100 yen for 10-15 minutes) and onsen baths for men and women.
reviews.title: Absolutely Magical Experience

likes.disliked: — Food may be a problem for those who don't like fish or seafood.

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed July 2010, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: This roykan was truly an experience. Miyajima is an experience, for that matter. Although it rained we thoroughly loved our two days spent there - was just incredibly relaxing and beautiful in every way. The Iwaso team will come and retrieve you from the boat when you arrive and then will bring you right to the hotel. The hotel itself is in the middle of the forest and from our room (which was simple and pretty, with a separate sitting area, in addition to the main room) you could hear the trickling of the stream below - so peaceful and lovely. We had our own toilet, bath and shower, although we did end up using the baths, which were fantastic (of course they are single sex). The food is also amazing - they served us kaiseki dinner both nights across the hall from our room in one of the rooms that wasn't being and kaiseki breakfast in the main dining room. The grounds were also absolutely beautiful!
reviews.title: WONDERFUL RYOKAN!!

reviews.text: Iwaso is definitely not cheap - was a "splurge" for us - but if you can afford it, I highly recommend staying for at least one night or two. It's just incredible.
reviews.title: Nice, but expensive
Disappointing
reviews.text: We had a lovely stay at Iwaso and we're really glad that we did stay there, but left feeling that we hadn't really got value for money.

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed March 2010, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: we had a corner room overlooking the pagoda and Torii gate (just) - very nice, immaculately clean. we weren't able to check in until gone 3pm (altho we didn't arrive until 1.30) unlike other ryokans we had stayed at during our visit to Japan.
reviews.title: Basic facilities and not very clean.

reviews.text: the dinner was great, altho not everything was to my friend's taste. The onsen was very nice, especially the outside area overlooking the stream. Note that the onsen is NOT available after 9.30am and then not until 3pm, which is disappointing if you are staying there more than one night. this is one of the things that irked us. another was being charged for bottled water - at the prices they are charging per night, it should be included.
reviews.title: Iwaso is an exquisite experience.
